thread.section_title: Dallas-Fort Worth Travel News and Destinations - News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: Texas & Neighbors: View fall foliage on Oklahoma scenic road trips
thread.title_full: Texas & Neighbors: View fall foliage on Oklahoma scenic road trips | Dallas Morning News

author: MARY DUNKLIN
title: Texas & Neighbors: View fall foliage on Oklahoma scenic road trips
text:
NEW ORLEANS Historic neighborhood celebrates with gumbo, jazz and more The eighth annual Tremé Creole Gumbo Festival is from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Nov. 14-15 at Louis Armstrong Park in New Orleans.
Enjoy many varieties of gumbo, even vegan options. Also included is an arts market with handmade crafts for purchase.
The fest, hosted by the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Foundation, celebrates one of the oldest neighborhoods of African-Americans in the U.S. Its musical history will be on display with many performances by artists native to the area. (Plus, keep an eye out for visiting musicians from the HBO series Tremé .)
Info: Armstrong Park, 701 N. Rampart St., New Orleans, La.; 504-558-6100; jazzandheritage.org/treme-gumbo
NEW MEXICO Annual crane festival is a paradise for bird lovers Bird lovers and nature photographers should make plans to visit the 28th annual Festival of the Cranes Nov. 17-22. The event, often called one of the top bird festivals in the country, celebrates the return of sandhill cranes, snow geese and more to the Bosque del Apache Refuge near Socorro.
Tours, seminars and hands-on events are included. Early morning outings let attendees get a rare view as thousands of cranes and geese take flight.
Experts will offer tips for photographing the birds in a variety of settings, and other workshops will explore their habitats, predators and characteristics.
Find the full schedule online, with prices for individual activities.
Info: Bosque del Apache Refuge, 1001 Highway 1, San Antonio, N.M., festivalofthecranes.com
COLORADO Ride the rails with Santa, elves this holiday season Book a trip on the Train to Christmas Town this winter.
Passengers board at the Rio Grande Scenic Railroad Depot in Alamosa for the festive hourlong ride. Santa and the elves will be on board to deliver a surprise to each child.
Everyone will enjoy cocoa, cookies and story time during the event.
The train runs Nov. 27-28, Dec. 4-5, 11-12, 18-20. There are three classes of service. Diamond Class offers seats in the upper dome cars with wide windows for viewing. First Class has seating at tables in vintage parlor cars. Standard Class is in a traditional railroad setting with rows of seats.
Tickets start at $28 for adults and $20 for children 2 to 12 years old.
Info: 1-877-726-7245; traintochristmastown.com/colorado
OKLAHOMA View fall colors on one of these scenic routes Now’s the time to start viewing the season’s changing colors. The Oklahoma Tourism & Recreation Department offers 14 route suggestions that offer prime views of fall foliage.
One of the drives, on the Talimena National Scenic Byway, takes visitors through the Ouachita National Forest across the tops of mountains in southeastern Oklahoma. Frequent scenic stops offer opportunities to hike, picnic and take pictures.
Late October through the first weeks of November is the best period to see peak foliage displays. Visit the website to find other suggested trips and excursions through the state.
Info: travelok.com/fall_foliage_and_festivals
Mary Dunklin
